Title:
Cranial anatomy and phylogenetic position of the
titanosaurian sauropod Bonitasaura salgadoi.
Keywords:
Argentina; Late Cretaceous; Ríio Negro; Sauropoda;
Titanosauria; skull
Abstract:
Knowledge of titanosaurian cranial anatomy has improved
substantially in the last decade because several skulls have come to
light or were restudied. The discovery of Bonitasaura salgadoi, a
partial titanosaurian skeleton including cranial bones, permitted the
definitive recognition of square jaws in a titanosaurian sauropod as
well as a peculiar skull morphology that increases the morphological
diversity of the group. Here we present a full description and
illustration of the skull material of B. salgadoi. Among cranial bones,
the lacrimal, quadrate, and dentary exhibit apomorphic differences from
those of other titanosaurians. Conversely, the frontal and parietal are
more conservative. Aphylogenetic analysis recovers B. salgadoi as a
member of the Titanosauria, related to mid-sized to large titanosauroids
from the Turonian-Campanian of South America, in contrast to a previous
hypothesis that suggested a nemegtosaurid affinity. The skull
reconstruction presented here shows that the skull of B. salgadoi is
anteroposteriorly short and dorsoventrally high, contrasting with the
elongate skull of Rapetosaurus krausei.
